Grove Calls DSRC'Most Active,
Efficient Group On Campus'
Neil Grove, President of the
DSRC, last week asserted in a
speech to the dormitory students
that the Council had "reached
the highest level of efficiency
and action ever attained."
Calling this year's council
members "the most responsible
and interested group of house
presidents ever to surround the
council table" Grove pointed to
the DSRC's highly successful
series of mixers as proof that "no
other organization can begin to
equal the council in co-operation,
hard work, and efficiency."
The Council was also given
credit for "initiating this year's
unparalleled era of increased
social relations with Hood College." According to Grove, it
was the Ccuncil's November 30
mixer when- "two busses full of
anxious dorm students converged
on Hood, which started the ball
rolling."
Turning to the Pajama Ball,
which the Council took on on
short notice "to save the fall
social schedule from ruins" Grove
asserted that no one who at-

67TH YEAR

Twenty-five Hopkins undergraduates have been selected for
this year's Who's Who in American Universities and Colleges.
The seniors so honored are listed
below.
They are: John Cox, track and
football; Peter Dow, Tau Beta
Pi; Tom Gleason, the Debate
Council; Jack Glock, N-L Business Manager; Neal Grove,
DSRC President; IFC President
Fred Kramer; and Paul Krouner,
Chairman of the BIA.
Also: Mel Lurie, captain of the
soccer team and AED President;
SAC Chairman Jim McClaine;
John Morgan, President of the
H-Club: Ed Morse, News-Letter,
Editor-in-Chief; Fred Nelson,
APO; and Ken Nobel, News-Letter Editor-in-Chief.
In addition: Zorel Paritsky
the Hullabaloo and ODK; Joe
Perotto, the SC and Cotillion
Board; Leon Poffenberger, baseball captain and football player;
Tom Prather, Musical Club; and
John Redfern of the YMCA.
Also: John Rogers, Booster
Club president; Mark Roter,
Hullabaloo Business Manager;
Thomas Spence Smith, NewsLetter Business Manager and
Honor Commission; Charles Van
Beke, Senior Class President:
Richard Webster, lacrosse captain; J. Bruce Williams Honor
Commission - Chairman;
and
James Ziegler of the JHU Band.
Once selected to Who's Who,
students are beset by a number
of
customers'
prerogatives:
whether or not to purchase the
heavy volume in which their
honor is explained, or more of
a number of honor keys offered.
Certificates will be presented
to all at the Senior Banquet,
later in the Spring.
The volume, published yearly,
includes the nominees of all of

the
participating
universities
and colleges in the nation, giving a sort of "curriculum vita"
for each student mentioned. This
publication is not to be confused
with Who's Who in America,
though it is an attempt at equivalence with that institution.

Annual Fete
Marks JHU's
87th Birthday
The 1963 annual Commemoration Day Exercises, celebrating
the 87th anniversary of the
founding of the University and
the 50th anniversary of the
School of Engineering Science,
will be held on Friday, February
22, in Shriver Hall at 3 p.m.
Dr. Milton S. Eienhower, President, will preside at the Convocation, and Dr. Abel Wolman,
Professor Emeritus of Sanitary
Engineering and Water Resources, will be the speaker.
Mr. Charles S. Garland, Chairman of the Board of Trustees,
and Dean Robert H. Roy, Professor of Industrial Engineering
and Dean of the School di Engineering Science, will also take
part in the ceremony.
This year the annual Alumni
Banquet will also honor the
School of Engineering Science.
To be held on Thursday, February 21, at the Sheraton-Belvedere Hotel, the banquet will
begin with a reception at 6 p.m.
Dr. John T. Rettaliata, President
of the Illinois Institute of Technology and an engineering alumnus, will be the principal speaker. Dean Roy will be the toastmaster.

Trustees Approve Two Three Visiting Profs
Teacher Promotions Come Next Semester
University Trustees, at the
last sitting of the board, approved the promotion of an Assistant Professor of Biological

and the appointment of a new
Assistant Professor in English
Literature.
David Robert Evans, who has
served the Hopkins Biology Department since 1958, will become
an Associate Professor effective
this July. Dr. Evans received the
Bachelor and Master of Science
degrees from the George Washington University, where he
studied from 1949-54.
The Johns Hopkins University
awarded him the Doctor of
Philosophy in 1957, and he
served as a post-doctoral researcher until 1958.
The Hopkins English Department will be increased with the
addition of John Malcolm Wallace as an Assistant Professor.
Dr. Wallace was born in London, has attended Trinity College (Cambridge), the College of
Saint Mark and Saint John at
London, Washington University
at Saint Louis, and received the
Doctor of Philosophy from Johns
Hopkins in 1960.
In 1959, he served as Visiting

Lecturer to the Shakespeare Academy at Stratford, Conn., and
since leaving Hopkins he has
held the position of Instructor
at Cornell University.

Hopkins Get Cancer Grant

Colleagues Honor
Late Dr. Berlin
Friends and former colleagues
of the late Dr. Theodore H. Berlin, noted theoretical physicist,
have established a memorial
lectureship at The John Hopkins
University bearing his name, it
was announced this week by
University officials.
Drs. Leon Mada.nsky and Gerhard Dieke, of the Hopkins
Physics Department, are inviting individuals and organizations
who were associated with Dr.
Berlin to contribute to a special
memorial fund which will establish the Theodore H. Berlin
Memorial Lectureship in the
Department of Physics at Johns
Hopkins.
Dr. Berlin, who died suddenly
last November at the age of 45,
spent fourteen years on the faculty at Hopkins.
"Deeply Saddened"
Drs. Madansky and Dieke, in
a joint statement said: "We were
all deeply saddened by the passing of Professor Berlin. Friends
and former colleagues at The
Johns Hopkins University have
thought there would be nothing
better to keep his memory alive
than a Memorial Lectureship
bearing his name. We were encouraged in this by his many
friends outside the University.
"While Ted Berlin had left
the University and was enthusiastically loyal to his new work,
he had spent most of his active
years at Johns Hopkins, and his
Interest and affection for the
University remained. One of the
activities which gave him a great
deal of pleasure here was to invite physicists for lectures and
conversation."
New Yorker
Dr. Berlin. a native of New
York, received his Ph.D. from the
University of Michigan in 1944.

Out Of The Dust
The January 19 issue of the Saturday Review contains a thoughtful article on the challenge facing higher
education in America. Summing up the duties of a
good college to itself and its undergraduates is the statement that "If our colleges can succeed in producing
graduates with a sense of mission, a deep, annoying
conscience about the social ills of man, and the courage
to help correct them, then higher education will have a
strategic place in society so long as man has problems
to be solved."
What catches our eye immediately is the concern
with the "social ills of man" and their correction. Such
"social awareness" is characteristic of the generation
which grew up in the twenties and thirties. They have
been accustomed from their youth to think of the world
in terms of social phenomena involving masses of men;
the "sense of mission" in society is central to their approach to life. Thus they have castigated our own generation because we seem uninterested in the problems
currently facing society as a whole, in such things as
integration and Peace.
What is not generally appreciated is that the profound social consciousness of previous generations has
given way to an equally profound, often anguished, self
consciousness. The deepest musings of today's undergraduate tend to an examination of himself rather than
his society. His concern is not to make a worthwhile
society, but to make himself what he considers a worthwhile human being. Perfecting the group has become
secondary to perfecting the individual.
Evidence for this change in undergraduate thinking
is the books he reads. Recent favorites have been Lord
of the Flies and the writings of J. D. Salinger, works
hich deal with the essential nature of the human
animal. Such social dramatists as Sinclair Lewis are
generally regarded as trivial and out of date. We all
know Babbit; we do not much like him, and we see no
point in anatomizing him at any length. Also, campus
political activity has, in general, declined—despite the
obvious vitality of C.O.R.E. et al. A Communist speaker
or a debate on Cuba arouses real interest but no fervor.
Even the thunder on the right cannot match the
cacaphony from the other end of the political spectrum
with which our fathers were famiilar.
We make no claims for the originality of this self
consciousness, it had engendered an extensive literature
long before we were born; nor will we attempt to defend
it. We simply point out that this generation is different
and that the social and political activities of the first
half of the century have given us the Bomb and the
Wall with no more adequate compensation than color
television.

Speaking of Institutions
The official opening, last week, of the Goucher College Center marks an exciting addition to the suburban
cultural setting and indicates how beneficial a privately
operated institution can he to the community in which it
is situated.
While the center will provide greater cultural and
social facilities for Goucherites, its serviceability to the
suburban community of Baltimore demonstrates the role
which educational institutions can play in the marketing
of culture to their geographically contiguous neighbors.

Juvenes Dum Sumus
Cornelius Lee Grove, DSRC president, has supplied
the News-Letter with a relentlessly prepared report (see
page 1) of the semester operations of the efficacious
dormitory council. While this report, which overflows
with superlatives, has satisfactorily demonstrated to U8
that student government can operate efficiently, it has
pleased our egos by demonstrating the perspicuity of our
judgment of last week.
Aside from a few events nominally sponsored by
the DSRC and more probably directed by its president
or a committee chairman, the council, like the other governing bodies on campus, has remained (and we quote
ourselves) "a mouthpiece which amuses itself on ordinary occasions in absolutely harmless procedural deliberations which satisfy the deliberators and trouble no one
else."

Review

Channels' Fitting,
Intelligently Done,
Wide-Ranging
A new Channels, with a prettier face and a more charming
content is ready for public consumption. Guided by a staff of
enthusiastic literary buffs, the
magazine demonstrates through
both form and content a sophisticated approach in providing
what it should, "a notebook of
literary interest."
While neither a journal of
avant-grade creative productivity nor a random selection of
mediocre prose and verse, Channels presents a positive attempt
at gathering together the new
campus writings of a relatively
small community. Its content exhibits a wide range of creative
IS THERE A CHAPERONE IN THE HOUSE?—(see corresattempts which often demonstrate surprising sophistication pondence, below.)
and never are boring.
The magazine's introduction,
perhaps stylized too closely with
that of the New Yorker attempts,
at times, to manifest a munificence of wit which too often
fails. A potpourri of literary gossip modeled somewhat like the
"Talk of the Town," this introduction moves from topic to
topic in the Dr. Macksey free
association
method
covering
everything from Channels to
John Steinbeck, William Golding, Bardy Levavy and P. G.
Wodehouse.
The formal aspects of the
magazine represent a tasteful
approach to an area of journalism which former Channels editors seemed to painstakingly
avoid. The editors used every
stylistic device in magazine
make-up that their limited budget allowed. The result is an
adequate wood-cut cover, an
abundant splattering of line
drawings and a utilization of two
types of book print paper.
The magazine sparkles with
intelligently rendered, sensitive
poetry and witty, humorous verse
which offset the general mediocrity of its fiction. Its general
presentation, however, as a
seriously rendered edition of an
undergraduate literary magazine
is commendable (E.M.).

INFERIORITY CAN BE FUN
The second gravest problem confronting college students today is inferiority feelings. (The first gravest problem is of
course, the recent outbreak of moult among sorority house
canaries.) Let us today look into the causes of inferiority
feelings and their possible cures.
Psychologists divide inferiority feelings into three principal
categories:
1. Physical inferiority.
2. Mental inferiority.
3. Financial inferiority.
(A few say there is also a fourth category: ichthyological
inferiority—a feeling that other people have prettier fish—
but I believe this is common only along the coasts and in the
Great Lakes area.)
Let us start with the feeling of physical inferiority, perhaps
the easiest to understand. Naturally we are inclined to feel
inferior to the brawny football captain or the beautiful homecoming queen. But we should not. Look at all the people,
neither brawny nor beautiful, who have made their marks in
the world. Look at Napoleon. Look at Socrates. Look at
Caesar. Look at Lassie.

re are &Titled'6/eeliffbiars

What I mean is that you can't always tell what's inside a
package by looking at the outside. (Sometimes, of course, you
can. Take Marlboro Cigarettes, for example. Just one glance
at that jolly red-and-white package—so bright and pert — so
neat but not gaudy—so perfectly in place whether you are at
a formal dinner or a beach picnic—so invariably correct for
any time, clime, or condition—one look, I say, at this paragon
of packs and you know it has to contain cigarettes of absolute
perfection. And you are right! That pure white Marlboro
filter, that fine, flavorful blend of Marlboro tobaccos, will
give you a smoke to make the welkin ring, whatever that is.
So those of you who have just been sitting and admiring your
Marlboro packs since the beginning of the semester, why don't
you open a pack and light one? Light a cigarette, I mean—
not the package. Then you can settle back and smoke your
Marlboro and, at the same time, continue to gaze rapturously
at the pack. Thus you will be twice as happy as you are if
that is possible.)
But I digress. Let us turn now to the second category—
mental inferiority. A lot of people think they are dumber than
other people. This is not so. It must be remembered that there
are different kinds of intelligence. Take, for instance, the classic case of the Sigafoos brothers, Claude and Sturbridge, students at Wake Forest. It was always assumed that Claude was
the more intelligent just because he knew more than Sturbridge about the arts, the sciences, the social sciences, the humanities, and like that. Sturbridge, on the other hand, was ten
times smarter than Claude when it came to tying granny knots.
But no matter; everybody looked down on "Stupid Sturbridge,"
as they called him and looked up at "Clever Claude," as they
called him. But who do you think turned out to be the smart
one when their granny almost got loose and ran away? You
guessed it—good old Stupid Sturbridge.
We arrive now at the final category, financial inferiority.
One way to deal with this condition is to increase your income.
You can, for example, become a fence. Or you can pose for a
life class, if your college is well heated.
But a better way to handle financial inferiority is to accept
it philosophically. Look on the bright side of poverty. True,
others may have more money than you have, but look at all
the things you have that they don't—debts, for instance, and
hunger cramps.
And what about friendship? You don't need money to have
friends, and let me tell you something, good people: the older
you get the more you will realize that nothing is so precious as
friendship, and the richest man in the world is the one with
the most money.

Colleagues Honor
Late Dr. Berlin
Friends and former colleagues
of the late Dr. Theodore H. Berlin, noted theoretical physicist,
have established a memorial
lectureship at The John Hopkins
University bearing his name, it
was announced this week by
University officials.
Drs. Leon Mada.nsky and Gerhard Dieke, of the Hopkins
Physics Department, are inviting individuals and organizations
who were associated with Dr.
Berlin to contribute to a special
memorial fund which will establish the Theodore H. Berlin
Memorial Lectureship in the
Department of Physics at Johns
Hopkins.
Dr. Berlin, who died suddenly
last November at the age of 45,
spent fourteen years on the faculty at Hopkins.
"Deeply Saddened"
Drs. Madansky and Dieke, in
a joint statement said: "We were
all deeply saddened by the passing of Professor Berlin. Friends
and former colleagues at The
Johns Hopkins University have
thought there would be nothing
better to keep his memory alive
than a Memorial Lectureship
bearing his name. We were encouraged in this by his many
friends outside the University.
"While Ted Berlin had left
the University and was enthusiastically loyal to his new work,
he had spent most of his active
years at Johns Hopkins, and his
Interest and affection for the
University remained. One of the
activities which gave him a great
deal of pleasure here was to invite physicists for lectures and
conversation."
New Yorker
Dr. Berlin. a native of New
York, received his Ph.D. from the
University of Michigan in 1944.

Out Of The Dust
The January 19 issue of the Saturday Review contains a thoughtful article on the challenge facing higher
education in America. Summing up the duties of a
good college to itself and its undergraduates is the statement that "If our colleges can succeed in producing
graduates with a sense of mission, a deep, annoying
conscience about the social ills of man, and the courage
to help correct them, then higher education will have a
strategic place in society so long as man has problems
to be solved."
What catches our eye immediately is the concern
with the "social ills of man" and their correction. Such
"social awareness" is characteristic of the generation
which grew up in the twenties and thirties. They have
been accustomed from their youth to think of the world
in terms of social phenomena involving masses of men;
the "sense of mission" in society is central to their approach to life. Thus they have castigated our own generation because we seem uninterested in the problems
currently facing society as a whole, in such things as
integration and Peace.
What is not generally appreciated is that the profound social consciousness of previous generations has
given way to an equally profound, often anguished, self
consciousness. The deepest musings of today's undergraduate tend to an examination of himself rather than
his society. His concern is not to make a worthwhile
society, but to make himself what he considers a worthwhile human being. Perfecting the group has become
secondary to perfecting the individual.
Evidence for this change in undergraduate thinking
is the books he reads. Recent favorites have been Lord
of the Flies and the writings of J. D. Salinger, works
hich deal with the essential nature of the human
animal. Such social dramatists as Sinclair Lewis are
generally regarded as trivial and out of date. We all
know Babbit; we do not much like him, and we see no
point in anatomizing him at any length. Also, campus
political activity has, in general, declined—despite the
obvious vitality of C.O.R.E. et al. A Communist speaker
or a debate on Cuba arouses real interest but no fervor.
Even the thunder on the right cannot match the
cacaphony from the other end of the political spectrum
with which our fathers were famiilar.
We make no claims for the originality of this self
consciousness, it had engendered an extensive literature
long before we were born; nor will we attempt to defend
it. We simply point out that this generation is different
and that the social and political activities of the first
half of the century have given us the Bomb and the
Wall with no more adequate compensation than color
television.

Speaking of Institutions
The official opening, last week, of the Goucher College Center marks an exciting addition to the suburban
cultural setting and indicates how beneficial a privately
operated institution can he to the community in which it
is situated.
While the center will provide greater cultural and
social facilities for Goucherites, its serviceability to the
suburban community of Baltimore demonstrates the role
which educational institutions can play in the marketing
of culture to their geographically contiguous neighbors.

Cornelius Lee Grove, DSRC president, has supplied
the News-Letter with a relentlessly prepared report (see
page 1) of the semester operations of the efficacious
dormitory council. While this report, which overflows
with superlatives, has satisfactorily demonstrated to U8
that student government can operate efficiently, it has
pleased our egos by demonstrating the perspicuity of our
judgment of last week.
Aside from a few events nominally sponsored by
the DSRC and more probably directed by its president
or a committee chairman, the council, like the other governing bodies on campus, has remained (and we quote
ourselves) "a mouthpiece which amuses itself on ordinary occasions in absolutely harmless procedural deliberations which satisfy the deliberators and trouble no one
else."

Channels' Fitting,
Intelligently Done,
Wide-Ranging
A new Channels, with a prettier face and a more charming
content is ready for public consumption. Guided by a staff of
enthusiastic literary buffs, the
magazine demonstrates through
both form and content a sophisticated approach in providing
what it should, "a notebook of
literary interest."
While neither a journal of
avant-grade creative productivity nor a random selection of
mediocre prose and verse, Channels presents a positive attempt
at gathering together the new
campus writings of a relatively
small community. Its content exhibits a wide range of creative
IS THERE A CHAPERONE IN THE HOUSE?—(see corresattempts which often demonstrate surprising sophistication pondence, below.)
and never are boring.
The magazine's introduction,
perhaps stylized too closely with
that of the New Yorker attempts,
at times, to manifest a munificence of wit which too often
fails. A potpourri of literary gossip modeled somewhat like the
"Talk of the Town," this introduction moves from topic to
topic in the Dr. Macksey free
association
method
covering
everything from Channels to
John Steinbeck, William Golding, Bardy Levavy and P. G.
Wodehouse.
The formal aspects of the
magazine represent a tasteful
approach to an area of journalism which former Channels editors seemed to painstakingly
avoid. The editors used every
stylistic device in magazine
make-up that their limited budget allowed. The result is an
adequate wood-cut cover, an
abundant splattering of line
drawings and a utilization of two
types of book print paper.
The magazine sparkles with
intelligently rendered, sensitive
poetry and witty, humorous verse
which offset the general mediocrity of its fiction. Its general
presentation, however, as a
seriously rendered edition of an
undergraduate literary magazine
is commendable (E.M.).

INFERIORITY CAN BE FUN
The second gravest problem confronting college students today is inferiority feelings. (The first gravest problem is of
course, the recent outbreak of moult among sorority house
canaries.) Let us today look into the causes of inferiority
feelings and their possible cures.
Psychologists divide inferiority feelings into three principal
categories:
1. Physical inferiority.
2. Mental inferiority.
3. Financial inferiority.
(A few say there is also a fourth category: ichthyological
inferiority—a feeling that other people have prettier fish—
but I believe this is common only along the coasts and in the
Great Lakes area.)
Let us start with the feeling of physical inferiority, perhaps
the easiest to understand. Naturally we are inclined to feel
inferior to the brawny football captain or the beautiful homecoming queen. But we should not. Look at all the people,
neither brawny nor beautiful, who have made their marks in
the world. Look at Napoleon. Look at Socrates. Look at
Caesar. Look at Lassie.

re are &Titled'6/eeliffbiars

What I mean is that you can't always tell what's inside a
package by looking at the outside. (Sometimes, of course, you
can. Take Marlboro Cigarettes, for example. Just one glance
at that jolly red-and-white package—so bright and pert — so
neat but not gaudy—so perfectly in place whether you are at
a formal dinner or a beach picnic—so invariably correct for
any time, clime, or condition—one look, I say, at this paragon
of packs and you know it has to contain cigarettes of absolute
perfection. And you are right! That pure white Marlboro
filter, that fine, flavorful blend of Marlboro tobaccos, will
give you a smoke to make the welkin ring, whatever that is.
So those of you who have just been sitting and admiring your
Marlboro packs since the beginning of the semester, why don't
you open a pack and light one? Light a cigarette, I mean—
not the package. Then you can settle back and smoke your
Marlboro and, at the same time, continue to gaze rapturously
at the pack. Thus you will be twice as happy as you are if
that is possible.)
But I digress. Let us turn now to the second category—
mental inferiority. A lot of people think they are dumber than
other people. This is not so. It must be remembered that there
are different kinds of intelligence. Take, for instance, the classic case of the Sigafoos brothers, Claude and Sturbridge, students at Wake Forest. It was always assumed that Claude was
the more intelligent just because he knew more than Sturbridge about the arts, the sciences, the social sciences, the humanities, and like that. Sturbridge, on the other hand, was ten
times smarter than Claude when it came to tying granny knots.
But no matter; everybody looked down on "Stupid Sturbridge,"
as they called him and looked up at "Clever Claude," as they
called him. But who do you think turned out to be the smart
one when their granny almost got loose and ran away? You
guessed it—good old Stupid Sturbridge.
We arrive now at the final category, financial inferiority.
One way to deal with this condition is to increase your income.
You can, for example, become a fence. Or you can pose for a
life class, if your college is well heated.
But a better way to handle financial inferiority is to accept
it philosophically. Look on the bright side of poverty. True,
others may have more money than you have, but look at all
the things you have that they don't—debts, for instance, and
hunger cramps.
And what about friendship? You don't need money to have
friends, and let me tell you something, good people: the older
you get the more you will realize that nothing is so precious as
friendship, and the richest man in the world is the one with
the most money.
